title: Wednesday, 25th April, 2018

BE11:08am

· The price of £12.50 per Sky Share represents:

· a premium of approximately 16 per cent. to the 21CF Offer of £10.75 for each Sky Share; and

· a premium of approximately 13 per cent. to the Closing Price of £11.05 per Sky Share on 26 February 2018, being the last Business Day before the announcement of Comcast's possible offer for Sky.

· The Cash Consideration implies a value of approximately £22.0 billion for the fully diluted share capital of Sky.

· In addition, Sky Shareholders shall be entitled to receive any final dividend in respect of the financial year ended 30 June 2018, up to an amount of 21.8p per Sky Share, which is declared and paid prior to the Effective Date.

BE11:08am

Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 3,889, down 41 (-1.04%), High: 4,091, Low: 3,861, Volume: 4.38m
wayneJ Also what happens to any cash for Skybet

Takeda bumps again, Shire says "yeah, okay". Takeda shares then crater and cut the readthrough bid price by about £2 a share to make the offer lower than the one Shire originally rejected.

BE11:11am

Takeda down 7% overnight.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

And even allowing for that, we're pricing in a huge failure discount here.

BE11:12am

For reasons that are pretty easy to summarise. Here's Barclays to do just that.

BE11:13am

The deal defies our early caution on probability of a deal being consummated, albeit we note it may be premature to assume this reaches completion just yet. At a minimum, we believe the shares are likely to trade at a wide discount to the nominal offer value given its unorthodox nature (i.e. to put it simply: a smaller company acquiring a larger one) and the manifold uncertainties that will prevail in advance of Shire shareholder actually getting paid (and how much that final payment will be worth). Accordingly, we believe that spread likely to be in the region of 20%....

Soundbuy Shire - was looking at £43 ish on opening......
J in Tokyo Takeda are now offering £21.75 cash and £24.85 in Takeda shares by my calculations.
11:13 am

BE11:14am

4.2x net debt/EBITDA!

Do bear in mind that pharma deals collapse a lot. Abbvie/Shire in 2014, of course, but also Pfizer/Allergan in 2016

.... I mean, Shire's been available to buyers forever. And it's entirely possible that Pfizer or whoever want bits of it, but the haemo and the legacy neurology stuff is unlikely to appeal greatly.

PeterC Morning, anything on Croda please?
BE11:20am

While it was unclear at first if Takeda would aggressively pursue an acquisition of SHPG - that question has now been answered. The question now is will other companies enter the fray?

BE11:21am

Media reports last week suggested that there could be “at least one, if not two” other bidders. And while AGN initially confirmed its interest, the company very quickly bowed out. We have long had SHPG on our "takeout" list from our series of industry reports entitled "Who is Next?".

11:21 am
BE11:21am

That said, we continue to think any potential group of buyers to be very limited. Additionally, it has now been four weeks since the initial disclosure that Takeda had interest and as we approach the original April 25th deadline for formalizing a merger agreement, it is still unclear if SHPG has started to run a “process” in an attempt to maximize shareholder value. At this point, its arguably less than a 50% chance that another suitor emerges. Finally, we continue to believe that an acquisition of SHPG will need to be consummated on a “friendly” basis as hostile takeovers in this sector have just not worked in recent years (e.g., MYL/PRGO, VRX/AGN, TEVA/MYL).

FATDAZ @Tax realist thanks for heads up that seems more like it and perhaps even a bit rich lol
wayneJ Re Shire - I have always wondered what proper dd would show in terms of potential product liability.
wayneJ And for anyone to really justify the acquisition of Shire requires you to invert to re-dom into Ireland ---- even Pfizer got stick for that. Not sure that Japanese shareholders will be enthused. Wonder what the normalised tax rate for the newco on a long term basis would be - and whether Takeda will disclose that in the shareholder docs.
Forester Whitbread & Croda please
Forester Whitbread - surely the most chameleon-like of British companies!

The shares have already risen 12% since Elliott’s stake was announced and are now trading in-line with our £42 SOTP price target (based on Costa at 10x FY20e EBITDA 19x P/E, £2.6bn), and as Costa is ~25% of group EBITDA (so 1x EBITDA is only 3% to the share price) we think investors need to believe in more than a Costa demerger to make an outsized return

FATDAZ not a direct comparison but forced to wonder why VC owners of Tim Horton's a very popular chain in Canada haven't rolled the brand out fully in UK may be the trials didn't go as planned ???

Having said that, Costa takeover speculation will likely only grow from here ...

FATDAZ @LondonBus thats what I imagined

The "oh, once they're split up Premier Inn and Costa will be takeover targets" idea seems prevalent this morning, at least among the sellside.

wayneJ @Swedish Chef - that is a bit random and asks for lots of questions? 'usual' - u live in the WTB hotel? u work there? Why Fort William? Perhaps u can serialise the ans....:-)
11:35 am
BE11:35am

Canaccord:

BE11:35am

Whitbread's in-line prelims are completely overshadowed by the announcement of the planned demerger of Costa Coffee, saying the timing is now right. We agree. There are no synergies from keeping the businesses together and the two management teams should thrive as separate entities. And if they slip-up, we think there will be plenty of suitors to underpin the respective share prices. We already expect the management teams of IHG, Marriott, and Accor to be doing their homework. We remain buyers with a 4500p target price. Our analysis suggests a potential break-up price of 5200p.

Londonbus @BE - IHG is virtually entirely franchised these days. Premier Inn would be an odd fit.
Bluesky21 IHG has Holiday Inn and Holiday Inn Express which is just above the price point of a Premier Inn
BE11:36am

And Panmure Gordon:

Bluesky21 Both Holiday Inn names quite strong in the UK
11:36 am
BE11:37am

Putting Premier Inn on 11x EBITDA and Pub/Restaurants on
8x, the current Whitbread share price values Costa at 9.4x EBITDA – not obviously cheap to our mind, although comparisons will be drawn with Starbucks (13x). We estimate each turn of Costa EV/EBITDA is worth c.£250m/140p per share. The challenge is why sell now when LFLs are flatling and market is worried about the high street, having rebutted demands to sell over the last 8 years when LFL averaged mid-single digit growth? WTB has aimed to address this concern, expecting completion within 24 months which allows for completion of critical transformation and infrastructure objectives. There is no mention of the other potential activist agenda, i.e. PI freehold assets, which increasingly feels like a non-starter.

Bluesky21 And Premier Inn is only in the UK
Londonbus @Bluesky - Accor or Marriott make more sense.
BE11:37am

(@ROTR: yeah, IHG for Premier seems a ludicrous idea. But we only quote this stuff.)

I've asked this before but I'll ask it again: why do you think Alison Brittain was targeted by activists when Andy Harrison wasn't?

Londonbus @Bluesky - yes but presumably you can have *brands*
Bluesky21 Because the business turns bad about the same time Alison Brittain took over, from overexpansion
11:38 am

undefined

Boohoo.Com PLC (BOO:LSE): Last: 176.95, up 22.55 (+14.60%), High: 181.90, Low: 169.05, Volume: 26.77m

FATDAZ re Premier Inn instead of trade sale why not securitise the income from the rooms and sell bonds to yield hungry investors?
BE11:41am

Rally, mostly. There had been a strong suspicion that Boohoo would cut margin guidance to reflect all the usual stuff that online retailers warn about -- costs mostly -- along with changes to its related-company sourcing model.

Bluesky21 @ Londonbus. I agree hotels can have brands but ideally you want syneriges too

FATDAZ Re Premier could even be a tranched deal based on occupancy
Bluesky21 I am not sure you can cross-sell anything to the Premier Inn customer base
11:43 am
BE11:43am

Peel Hunt can summarise:

BE11:43am

boohoo has announced a strong set of final results, with revenue,
gross profit, EBITDA and PBT all coming in well ahead of
consensus and our top-of-the-range forecasts. Critically, fears of
a ‘margin reset’ have not been realised, with management
guiding to EBITDA margins of 9-10% for the year ahead. We
upgrade FY19 PBT by 12.8% to £68.4m. With a strong start to
the new year, this year’s revenue guidance once again looks like
a number to beat, particularly given the strong set of trading
KPIs. Changes to distribution plans means the next move is
likely to be overseas.

BE11:44am

Fears of a ‘margin reset’ look misplaced. boohoo points to EBITDA margins of 9-10% for FY19, with conservative revenue growth of 35-40%. Given that the new year has started well, revenue guidance looks like a number to beat again, particularly with respect to PLT, noting revenue growth last year of 228% and active customer growth of 128%. This creates a guidance revenue range of £783m-812m and an EBITDA range of £70.5m-81.2m (vs cons £72.6m). Our upgraded forecasts assume 47% revenue growth and 9.4% EBITDA margins, driving a 5% EBITDA upgrade to £80m. At a PBT level, the upgrade is greater, +12.8% to £68.4m, reflecting a lower depreciation charge due to the lack of supersite. Reiterate BUY.

TheDubliner Any grey on Tullow Oil after their update today?
wayneJ @Swedish Chef - a cat called Tom has some views on that one.
FATDAZ re boohoo Liberum retail must be smiling on that move up in the stock
11:45 am
BE11:45am

And Citi.

BE11:45am

The FY19e guidance for +35-40% revenue growth and 9-10% adj EBITDA margins implies small (c.4%) upgrades to consensus at the mid-point and the company has stated that longer term growth of +25% at more than 9% adj EBITDA margin is sustainable. Alongside reduced near term capex this is likely to reassure investors worried about sustainability of profits and cashflow.

BE11:46am

And Barclays.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Investors have been understandably nervous ahead of Boohoo’s FY18 results, with lots of questions on the balance of growth and margin. We think these results to some degree reassure – FY18 is a bit better on margins and the FY19 guidance more than sanctions consensus with no change to outer year margin expectations. They aren’t totally free of anything to pick at: core Boohoo has slowed in P4 and they need to execute well on the PLT warehouse migration this year. But they are broadly positive.

Taking a step back, we think this set of numbers was never going to be enough to fully convince bears, who can push their case sideways. But they are a step on the road. We think the shares have been oversold and are Overweight. The shares trade on 38x CY19 EPS.

Grouchmonkey @Wayne Winnifrith on Woodford? an entertaining read.....
BE11:47am

For the more negative stuff on Boohoo, you'll need to Google.

undefined

11:50 am
BE11:51am

Okay, so Croda quickly.

Croda International Plc (CRDA:LSE): Last: 4,398, down 221 (-4.78%), High: 4,480, Low: 4,391, Volume: 320.51k
BE11:51am

It's a miss. Sales £356m versus £368m consensus.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Organic growth 4.0% vs consensus 4.7%.

BE11:52am

Reason for the miss is the low-margin industrial chemicals side.

BE11:53am

Plus a day off for Easter, which -- amazingly -- the consensus seems not to have captured.

nichoman ah thanks
MonkeyBusiness makes sense from an excel spreadsheet point of view
11:53 am
BE11:53am

Guidance is unchanged and the gist from management is going for quality rather than chasing volume, so you could argue that today's weakness looks a bit harsh.

BE11:53am

Here's UBS.

BE11:54am

Organic growth in the core businesses (i.e. excluding the low margin Industrial Chems) was 4.0% against +5.6% for FY2017 and UBSe for 1Q of 5.7%. Personal Care growth was 7.6% (UBSe +5.0%, FY17 of 5.3%), which bodes well for the group margin (Personal Care generated margins 38% above the group average in 2017). Life Sciences organic was 4.1% versus UBSe of 10.0% and FY17 of 4.6%. The more industrial-facing Perf Tech division delivered organic growth of 0.2% (UBSe +2.0% and FY17 of 6.6%), partly due to tough comparatives but also "reduced sales volume in lower margin products, moving the sector towards its margin target of 20%". FX provided a headwind to sales of -5.3% (UBSe -6.9%).

11:54 am
BE11:54am

We envisage a neutral share price reaction, with an organic miss being compensated by a likely stronger than expected margin. Our Buy rating is based on the attractive combination of organic investment in renewables and balance sheet opportunities (net debt/EBITDA should be 0.6x by the end of 2018 without either M&A or a special dividend). We would also re-emphasise that management has stated that it would be willing to look at transformational M&A opportunities at the right price.

Londonbus I see Sky is going to have pay 21CF £200m. Ouch.
BE11:55am

And JP Morgan.

BE11:55am

We note that one less working day in Europe/LatAm is estimated by the company to have impacted 1Q growth by ~100bps. Personal Care division CC sales growth of 7.6% (JPMe: 5.5%) stood out and was driven equally by higher volumes and price/mix improvement with the latter allowing the company to offset higher raw material costs. Growth in other divisions was materially weaker than our expectations. EBIT margin increased slightly YoY in 1Q18, indicating to us that the current Bloomberg cons of 80bps margin improvement for FY18 is likely high. Further, the recent small acquisition of Plant Impact will have a £3-4m headwind on FY18 earnings. Hence, we trim our FY18E EPS by 0.6% to 185p but maintain our FY19/20E EPS with our EPS estimates ~3% lower than cons. Stock trades on 25x/23x FY18/19E EPS vs. last three years’ median of 20.8x

11:56 am
BE11:56am

And Morgan Stanley, off the conference all and reaching the same conclusion as I did.

Waterloo @londonbus, read it again. DF21 don;t have to pay the £200m
BE11:57am

We expected Croda's shares to underperform initially on the organic growth 'miss'. But we also expect this underperformance to unwind following the analyst call as the market gets more visibility on the strength of the underlying business.

BE11:57am

What did we learn? (1) there's no evidence of a slowdown, and adjusting for the Par contract termination and de-marketing in PT, organic growth rates remain strong; (2) don't forget about margins... "quality" growth has always been more important to Croda and higher margins, especially in PT, will be a more notable feature of 2018 than we expected; (3) in Personal care, growth is surprising to the upside, with MNCs growing as fast as SMEs right now; (4) the timing of Easter knocked ~1% off of organic growth, which is sizeable and was not in the initial press release; and (5) April trading is showing some strong trends in terms of organic growth.
